notes_translated.fr:
"Cet ensemble de données présente les résultats obtenus par deux réseaux de surveillance radiologique exploités par Santé Canada, soit les sites de surveillance canadiens mis en place dans le cadre du Traité d'interdiction complète des essais nucléaires (TICEN) et le Réseau canadien de surveillance radiologique (RCSR).  Pour plus de renseignements sur le TICEN et son réseau de surveillance, consultez les sites : http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/ewh-semt/contaminants/radiation/nuclea/index-fra.php et http://www.ctbto.org/. Pour plus de renseignements sur le RCSR, visitez le site : http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/ewh-semt/contaminants/radiation/crmn-rcsr/index-fra.php.
Les résultats indiquent l'activité volumique de divers nucléides durant les mois qui ont suivi l'accident nucléaire de Fukushima-Daiichi et précisent le degré d'incertitude qui s'y rapporte. Les rapports portent sur deux radionucléides naturels, le béryllium 7 (7Be) et le plomb 210 (210Pb), tous les radionucléides anthropiques détectés, à savoir le césium 134 (134Cs), le césium 136 (136Cs), le césium 137 (137Cs), l'iode 131 (131I), l'iode 132 (132I), l'iode 133 (133I), le tellure 129 (129Te), le tellure 129m (129mTe), le tellure 132 (132Te), le technétium 99m (99mTc), le lanthane 140 (140La), ainsi que les gaz radioactifs xénon 131m (131mXe), xénon 133 (133Xe), xénon 133m (133mXe) et xénon 135 (135Xe). L'absence de données sur un nucléide particulier signifie soit que le nucléide était absent, soit que sa concentration était inférieure au seuil de détection. Les données proviennent de la mesure et de l'analyse des particules captées par les matériaux filtrants ou du gaz xénon extrait de l'atmosphère. Des facteurs de correction ont été appliqués aux sommations en cascade pour s'assurer que les résultats reflètent les véritables relations physiques entre les radionucléides détectés.
Durant toute la période à l'étude, l'activité volumique de l'ensemble des radionucléides mesurés n'a représenté qu'une faible proportion de l'exposition de fond annuelle typique qui provient des sources naturelles de rayonnement.  Ces niveaux ne présentent donc pas de risque pour la santé des Canadiens. 
"
notes_translated.en:
"This dataset provides the results obtained by two radiation monitoring networks operated by Health Canada:  the Canadian monitoring sites of the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty (CTBT) and the Canadian Radiological Monitoring Network (CRMN).  More information about the CTBT and its monitoring network is available here:  http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/ewh-semt/contaminants/radiation/nuclea/index-eng.php and http://www.ctbto.org/. Further information on the CRMN network is available at:   http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/ewh-semt/contaminants/radiation/crmn-rcsr/index-eng.php.
The results provided are activity concentration and uncertainty for various nuclides in the months following the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear accident. Reported are the naturally occurring radionuclides: beryllium-7 (7Be) and lead-210 (210Pb), and all anthropogenic radionuclides observed: cesium-134 (134Cs), cesium-136 (136Cs), cesium-137 (137Cs), iodine-131 (131I), iodine-132 (132I), iodine-133 (133I), tellurium-129 (129Te), tellurium-129m (129mTe), tellurium-132 (132Te), technetium-99m (99mTc), lanthanum-140 (140La), and the radioactive gases: xenon-131m (131mXe), xenon-133 (133Xe), xenon-133m (133mXe), and xenon-135 (135Xe). The absence of data for a specific nuclide indicates that it was either below the detection threshold or absent. The data comes from the measurement and analysis of particulates accumulated in filter media or from xenon gas extracted from the atmosphere. Cascade summations corrections were applied to ensure reporting of the true physical relationships among the observed radionuclides.
Throughout the accident period, the measured activity concentrations of all radionuclides represent only a small fraction of the typical annual background exposure from natural sources of radiation.  Therefore, these levels do not present any risks to the health of Canadians. 
"

fr: Traité d'interdiction complète des essais nucléaires

subject: health_and_safety

title_translated.fr: Mesures des aérosols et des gaz rares radioactifs durant l'accident nucléaire de Fukushima-Daiichi
title_translated.en: Aerosol and Noble Gas Radioactivity Measurements during the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Accident

data_series_name.en: The Canadian Radiological Monitoring Network’s Environmental Radioactivity Surveillance Data

notes:
"This dataset provides the results obtained by two radiation monitoring networks operated by Health Canada:  the Canadian monitoring sites of the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty (CTBT) and the Canadian Radiological Monitoring Network (CRMN).  More information about the CTBT and its monitoring network is available here:  http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/ewh-semt/contaminants/radiation/nuclea/index-eng.php and http://www.ctbto.org/. Further information on the CRMN network is available at:   http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/ewh-semt/contaminants/radiation/crmn-rcsr/index-eng.php.
The results provided are activity concentration and uncertainty for various nuclides in the months following the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear accident. Reported are the naturally occurring radionuclides: beryllium-7 (7Be) and lead-210 (210Pb), and all anthropogenic radionuclides observed: cesium-134 (134Cs), cesium-136 (136Cs), cesium-137 (137Cs), iodine-131 (131I), iodine-132 (132I), iodine-133 (133I), tellurium-129 (129Te), tellurium-129m (129mTe), tellurium-132 (132Te), technetium-99m (99mTc), lanthanum-140 (140La), and the radioactive gases: xenon-131m (131mXe), xenon-133 (133Xe), xenon-133m (133mXe), and xenon-135 (135Xe). The absence of data for a specific nuclide indicates that it was either below the detection threshold or absent. The data comes from the measurement and analysis of particulates accumulated in filter media or from xenon gas extracted from the atmosphere. Cascade summations corrections were applied to ensure reporting of the true physical relationships among the observed radionuclides.
Throughout the accident period, the measured activity concentrations of all radionuclides represent only a small fraction of the typical annual background exposure from natural sources of radiation.  Therefore, these levels do not present any risks to the health of Canadians. 
"
title: Aerosol and Noble Gas Radioactivity Measurements during the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Accident
